title: 106_s2463
content: The Act titled "National Death Penalty Moratorium Act of 2000" establishes a moratorium on the death penalty. Congress finds that death sentences are disproportionately imposed on the poor and certain racial and ethnic groups, with African-Americans being overrepresented in executions and on death row. No state meets ABA standards for indigent prisoners' legal representation. The death penalty system in the Federal system shows racial disparities, with a high percentage of white victims in death penalty cases. Studies have shown that a majority of defendants selected for capital prosecution are African-American or Hispanic American. The General Accounting Office reported racial disparities in charging, sentencing, and imposition of the death penalty. Prisoner appeals have been limited, increasing the risk of imprisoning and executing innocent individuals. The Supreme Court has restricted death row prisoners' rights to appeal convictions and sentences in Federal courts, even with compelling evidence of innocence. Legislation in 1996 limited Federal court review of death penalty appeals and reduced public funding for legal aid services for death row prisoners. The Federal Government and States are prohibited from carrying out the death penalty until Congress reviews the final findings and recommendations of the National Commission on the Death Penalty. This moratorium will remain in place until legislation is enacted based on the Commission's guidelines and procedures. The National Commission on the Death Penalty is established with 15 members appointed by the President. The Commission includes prosecutors, defense attorneys, judges, law enforcement officials, and individuals with expertise in relevant matters. The National Commission on the Death Penalty is established with 15 members appointed by the President, including individuals from the public or private sector with expertise in relevant matters. The President must ensure a balanced membership with varying opinions on the use of the death penalty. Initial appointments should be made within 30 days. The National Commission on the Death Penalty is established with 15 members appointed by the President, including individuals with expertise in relevant matters. Members serve for the life of the Commission, vacancies are filled promptly, and the Chairperson calls meetings. The President designates a Chair, and the Commission adopts rules for its proceedings. Members serve for the life of the Commission, vacancies are filled promptly, and the Chairperson calls meetings. The President designates a Chair, and the Commission adopts rules for its proceedings. SEC. 202. DUTIES OF THE COMMISSION. The Commission is tasked with conducting a study on the administration of the death penalty to ensure it aligns with constitutional principles of fairness, justice, and due process. This study includes examining racial disparities, geographic and income-based disproportionality in sentencing decisions, and the adequacy of legal representation for capital defendants. The Commission is studying the administration of the death penalty to ensure fairness and due process. Key issues include wrongful convictions, federal involvement in state cases, judicial review of constitutional claims, sentencing of mentally disabled and juvenile offenders, and procedures for those sentenced to death. The Commission is studying the administration of the death penalty to ensure fairness and due process, including guidelines for sentencing mentally disabled and juvenile offenders. Procedures are being established to guarantee access to forensic evidence and DNA testing for potential new evidence of innocence in death penalty cases. The guidelines and procedures for death penalty cases aim to ensure fairness, minimize the risk of executing innocent individuals, and prevent racial discrimination. The Commission will submit a preliminary report within a year and a final report within two years of the Act's enactment to the President, Attorney General, and Congress. The Commission will submit a report with findings, conclusions, and recommendations for legislation and administrative actions to the President, Attorney General, and Congress after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 203. POWERS OF THE COMMISSION. The Commission has the power to obtain information from Federal and State agencies, use postal services, accept gifts, and conduct hearings as necessary for carrying out its provisions. The Commission has the authority to issue subpoenas for witnesses and documents, with enforcement through district courts. The court may order individuals to testify or provide evidence, failure to comply may result in contempt charges. A court can issue a writ of habeas corpus ad testificandum to produce a person in custody before the Commission. Witness allowances and fees are governed by section 1821 of title 28, United States Code. SEC. 204. COMMISSION PERSONNEL MATTERS. Members of the Commission serve without compensation but are allowed travel expenses. The Chairperson can appoint an executive director and necessary personnel without following civil service laws, and set their compensation. The Chairperson of the Commission has the authority to set compensation for the executive director and staff without following certain civil service laws. Federal Government employees can be detailed to the Commission without reimbursement, and temporary services can be procured at specified rates. SEC. 205. TERMINATION OF THE COMMISSION. The Commission will end 90 days after submitting its report. SEC. 206. FUNDING. The Commission can spend up to $850,000 to carry out its duties, funded by the Department of Justice.
